qas.question: What three free Slavic states were in the world as of 1878?

answers.text: the Russian Empire, Serbia and Montenegro

qas.question: When were the Russian Empire, Serbia, and Montenegro the only free Slavic states in the world?
Whose official independence was declared in 1908?
When were independent states as Czechoslovakia, the Second Polish Republic, and the State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs established?
What was Serbia de jure vassal to in 1878?
How many people were in the Ottoman Empire?
How many Slavs lived in Czechoslovakia?

context: As of <a1_0>1878<a1_0/>, there were only three free Slavic states in the world: <a0_0>the Russian Empire, Serbia and Montenegro<a0_0/>. <a2_0>Bulgaria<a2_0/> was also free but was de jure vassal to <b4_0>the Ottoman Empire<b4_0/> until official independence was declared in <b5_0>1908<b5_0/>. In the entire Austro-Hungarian Empire of approximately <b6_0>50 million people<b6_0/>, about <b8_0>23 million<b8_0/> were Slavs. The Slavic peoples who were, for the most part, denied a voice in the affairs of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, were calling for national self-determination. During World War I, representatives of the Czechs, Slovaks, Poles, Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes set up organizations in the Allied countries to gain sympathy and recognition. <a3_0>In 1918<a3_0/>, after <b7_0>World War I<b7_0/> ended, the Slavs established such independent states as Czechoslovakia, the Second Polish Republic, and the State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs.
